node.title: Investors Hung Their Hats on Peloton and Zoom Last Year. What Now?
node.description: Some “stay-at-home” stocks that were pandemic-era darlings have experienced brutal sell-offs.
node.content: ["Peloton\u2019s pricey exercise bikes were the hot product for fitness buffs in the early days of the pandemic. With jumbo screens and upbeat instructors, being on them mimicked the experience of an in-person spin class in their living rooms.", "What happens now that they can get the real thing again?", "Shares of companies like Peloton and Zoom Video, the online conference software that replaced face-to-face communications for countless schools and businesses, were darlings of the stock market for the better part of last year. But as the economic reopening gains speed \u2014 aided by rising vaccination numbers and promising new treatments for those who get sick \u2014 some of the stocks at the center of the so-called stay-at-home trade collapsed.", "\u201cThe markets clearly sense the pandemic is over,\u201d said Ben Emons, managing director of global macro strategy for Medley Global Advisors. \u201cWe\u2019re in a full reopening, and we\u2019re moving toward a normalized situation.\u201d", "That has been bad news for the share prices of some of last year\u2019s hottest stocks. Peloton dived 35 percent in a single trading session this month, after it deeply cut its sales forecast for the coming year. Peloton\u2019s chief executive, John Foley, said on a conference call with analysts that the company knew it would be a challenge to duplicate the results it had during the peak of the pandemic. But he added, \u201cOur long-term thesis of fitness moving into the home is unchanged.\u201d", "On Tuesday, Peloton\u2019s shares jumped 15.5 percent after a $1 billion stock offering to raise cash, but are still down nearly 64 percent for the year.", "Other once-hot stocks have also skidded. Shares of the online education company Chegg plunged almost 50 percent in a single trading session on Nov. 2, and are off 67 percent in 2021. Zoom Video plummeted 17 percent on a single day in late August, after it noted that strong demand for its products showed signs of easing as the pandemic abated. So far this year, it\u2019s down nearly 22 percent.", "Instead, many investors are shifting their attention to corners of the market they considered no-go zones last year, with businesses including airlines, live events companies and commercial real estate firms posting large gains.", "The turn away from stay-at-home stocks hasn\u2019t sapped the market\u2019s overall momentum. The S&P 500 closed up 0.4 percent on Tuesday, hovering near another record high, and is up more than 25 percent this year. After the index\u2019s head-spinning recovery last year, and a nearly 29 percent gain in 2019, stocks are on track for the best three-year run since the late 1990s.", "Investors owe the bulk of the market\u2019s gain this year to so-called cyclical stocks, such as oil companies and financial firms, whose profits and share prices tend to mirror the trajectory of the economy, rising and falling as growth quickens or slows.", "It\u2019s a stark switch from the kinds of stocks that were at the epicenter of last year\u2019s remarkable rise \u2014 and a huge surge in trading.", "As lockdowns forced much of the country to stay home \u2014 often with ample extra money from government stimulus and little else to do \u2014 millions of neophytes tried their hand at trading stocks. Many of them bought shares in the products they were being exposed to for the first time, like Peloton, or those they were using more frequently, like Clorox. The logic was fairly straightforward: As the economy went through one of the worst economic shocks on record, these companies seemed like they\u2019d be able to grow profitably through, and perhaps because of, the crisis.", "\u201cThe stay-at-home stocks were the place to be because that was where the growth was,\u201d said Eric Mintz, portfolio manager at Eagle Asset Management, an investment firm in St. Petersburg, Fla.", "It was a disparate group of stocks: Shares of Zoom Video were up nearly 400 percent last year while Peloton rose about 470 percent.", "The online retailer Etsy, which suddenly became a key source of homemade masks, jumped 300 percent. And the internet furniture store Wayfair rose 150 percent as people nestled down and spruced up their homes.", "At the end of last year, one of the funds Mr. Mintz co-manages \u2014 the roughly $9 billion Carillon Eagle Mid Cap Growth Fund \u2014 owned sizable stakes in one of those stocks, a slug of Peloton shares worth roughly $136 million.", "But in the first half of 2021, the fund sold out of that position and has built stakes in companies that are tied to infrastructure spending, home improvement and health care, and that Mr. Mintz thinks offer strong potential for growth over the near term.", "\u201cWhen you\u2019ve got this surge in reopenings, obviously you\u2019ve got a number of companies doing very well, and industries,\u201d he said, adding that as the economy improves, growth-focused investors don\u2019t need to crowd into \u201cjust a handful of stocks.\u201d", "Not every company that surged over the past 20 months has come back to earth.", "Etsy, for example, is up roughly 60 percent in 2021, as the company has been successful at converting those who went to the site for face coverings into repeat customers. And the online security company Zscaler \u2014 which soared more than 300 percent last year \u2014 has only continued to climb, rising more than 70 percent so far this year.", "\u201cThe market liked to group them all together: the pandemic trade vs. the reopening,\u201d said Chris Mack, a stock portfolio manager at the investment adviser Harding Loevner in Bridgewater, N.J. \u201cThe market, now, is having to go through and look at the underlying fundamentals. There are company-specific differences.\u201d", "Recent earnings reports have provided some answers \u2014 and sometimes violent investor reactions. Shares of Chegg \u2014 which provides digital textbook rental and online tutoring \u2014 fell by half earlier this month, wiping out more than $4 billion of market value, after quarterly results fell just short of expectations. The company was seeing \u201csignificantly fewer enrollments than expected this semester\u201d as more customers cut back on their studies to return to work, Chegg\u2019s chief executive, Daniel Rosensweig, told analysts.", "Peloton\u2019s big drop came after it also missed earnings expectations, with a single day of losses accounting for much of its nearly 64 percent decline this year. (Planet Fitness disclosed much better than expected results the same day, as a surge of new customers pushed its gym memberships to 97 percent of the company\u2019s peak. Its shares are up 16 percent this month.)", "But the pandemic darlings aren\u2019t finished, even if their most explosive growth has petered out. Some investors believe that nearly two years of stay-at-home life have so altered our behaviors that companies like Peloton and Zoom Video will remain part of our daily routines for the foreseeable future.", "Bill Cynecki, a 31-year-old military officer living in Milford, Mich., said he had been a true believer in Peloton since \u201c10 minutes\u201d into his first ride, when he tried one of the bikes out while visiting his sister in Manhattan in February 2020.", "Mr. Cynecki began buying shares when the stock was trading around $30, then held on as the pandemic drove it up to $150 by the end of the year. He sold a bit then, but bought more shares when it fell below $100.", "On Tuesday, Peloton closed at $54.85 a share.", "\u201cObviously, you know, hard times right now,\u201d said Mr. Cynecki, who still believes that Peloton will have a strong business over the long term. \u201cBut this is a part of investing.\u201d"]
